case_name: State Bank of India v. R. K. Jain

facts.text: State Bank of India filed Civil Appeal No. 992 of 1967 by special leave against the award dated April 7, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal, Chandigarh.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 992 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated April 7, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal, Chandigarh in Reference No. 4C

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal award dated April 7, 1967 set aside the order discharging R.K. Jain and directed his reinstatement with full back wages.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, by the State Bank of India, is against the award dated April 7, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal, Chandigarh, setting aside the order of the appellant, discharging

facts.text: R.K. Jain joined service of State Bank of India on June 13, 1955 as a Money Tester at Ambala City Branch.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent joined the service of the appellant on June 13, 1955 as a Money Tester and was working in that capacity at the Ambala City Branch in July, 1960.

facts.text: On July 26, 1960, R.K. Jain was deputed to supervise remittance of unissuable notes worth Rs. 87,48,000/- from Ambala City Branch to RBI Ludhiana for destruction.

anchor.surface_text: On July 26, 1960, he was deputed to supervise the remittance of unissuable numberes of Rs. 87,48,000/- from the Ambala City Branch to the Note Cancellation and Verification Sections

facts.text: Shortage of Rs. 100/- (10 notes of Rs. 10 denomination) found in a packet bearing initials of R.K. Jain when delivered to RBI Ludhiana.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, when the money was taken by the first respondent on July 26, 1.960 and delivered to the Note Cancellation and Verification Section of the Reserve Bank of India, Ludhiana,

facts.text: R.K. Jain tore off the label bearing his initials from the shortage packet despite protests by RBI officials.

anchor.surface_text: R. K. Jain, under the guise of trying to unstitch the packet, tore off the label bearing his initials in spite of the protest made by the officials of the Reserve Bank of India.

facts.text: R.K. Jain admitted shortage in letter dated July 29, 1960 to RBI, stating slip torn inadvertently.

anchor.surface_text: Later on., a verbal inquiry was made by the Superintendent of the Reserve Bank of India and R. K. Jain admitted the shortage by his letter dated July 29, 1960.

facts.text: Ambala City Branch sent letter dated August 13, 1960 to R.K. Jain holding him responsible for shortage and alleging he tore label to avoid liability.

anchor.surface_text: Ambala City Branch of the appellant, addressed a letter dated August 13 , 1960 to R. K. Jain regarding the reports made by the Currency Officer, Reserve Bank of India

facts.text: R.K. Jain replied on August 16, 1960 denying deliberate tearing, claiming accidental, and alleging bias by RBI staff.

anchor.surface_text: On August 16, 1960, the first respondent stated that the packet companytaining soiled numberes was handled by several persons and companynted more than once

facts.text: R.K. Jain suspended with effect from September 6, 1960 pending inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: Not satisfied with the explanation given by R. K. Jain, the appellant placed him under suspension with effect from September 6, 1960 pending an inquiry

facts.text: Charge sheet issued to R.K. Jain on October 10, 1960 alleging shortage responsibility and deliberate tearing of label.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated October 10, 1960, R. Jain was required to show cause why disciplinary action should number be taken against him on the following charges

facts.text: R.K. Jain replied to charges on October 18, 1960 denying deliberate actions and alleging RBI staff prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: K. Jain sent his explanation to the charges by his letter dated October 18, 1960. While admitting that he was deputed on July 26, 1960

facts.text: First departmental inquiry by B.P. Tiwari commenced December 23, 1960, report February 2, 1961 finding R.K. Jain guilty.

anchor.surface_text: It is seen that there was a Departmental Inquiry companyducted by one B. P. Tiwari, an officer of the Appellant Branch at Ambala. The inquiry companymenced on December 23, 1960

facts.text: RBI witnesses refused cross-examination in first inquiry by B.P. Tiwari.

anchor.surface_text: Those officers surprisingly refused to be cross-examined by the first respondent during that inquiry.

facts.text: Second inquiry ordered by management due to defects in first inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: It is stated by the appellant that when the report of B. P. Tiwari was companysidered, the grievance made on behalf of R. K. Jain in the letter dated December 24, 1960

facts.text: Second inquiry by B.D. Sharma notified May 27, 1961, commenced June 14, 1961, ended July 12, 1962, report August 23, 1962 finding guilty.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the new Inquiry Officer B. D. Sharma sent a companymunication dated May 27, 1961 to R. K. Jain that he will be companyducting another inquiry

facts.text: R.K. Jain and Staff Association protested second inquiry as unfair labour practice.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this companymunication the Deputy General Secretary of the State Bank of India Staff Association sent a reply on June 10, 1961 to D. D. Sharma stating

facts.text: Inquiry Officer B.D. Sharma rejected summoning of witnesses Pooran Singh and Sanjhi Ram, requiring R.K. Jain to produce at own expense.

anchor.surface_text: The Inquiry Officer rejected the request of R. K. Jain regarding three of those witnesses on the ground that their evidence will number be useful for the inquiry.

facts.text: Show cause notice dated March 4, 1963 proposing discharge without notice based on second inquiry findings.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of the report, the Superintendent of the Ambala City Branch of the appellant by his letter dated March 4, 1963 intimated R. K. Jain

facts.text: R.K. Jain replied March 28, 1963 alleging violations of natural justice in inquiries.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent sent a reply on March 28, 1963 pleadinginnocence. In the said reply he alleged that the first inquiry by B. P. Tiwari

facts.text: R.K. Jain discharged from service without notice on October 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Superintendent of the appellant branch at Ambala, by his ,order dated October 1, 1963 discharged R. K. Jain from the service of the Bank

facts.text: Appeal against discharge filed November 8, 1963, rejected January 18, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent filed an appeal on November 8, 1963 before the Deputy Secretary and Treasurer of the appellant Bank at New Delhi.

facts.text: Central Government referred dispute on September 19, 1966 to Industrial Tribunal Chandigarh.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government by its order dated September 19, 1966 referred for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal, Chandigarh the following dispute

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held second inquiry violated natural justice by not summoning witnesses, set aside discharge.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, by its award dated April 7, 1967, held that R. K. Jain was number afforded a reasonable opportunity to produce evidence

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld Tribunal finding that second inquiry not at instance of workman.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, Mr. Ramamurthi is well founded in his companytention and the view of the Industrial Tribunal in this regard is companyrect.

facts.text: Supreme Court held denial of summoning Pooran Singh and Sanjhi Ram violated natural justice given circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Under those circumstances, in our opinion, the Tribunal was justified in holding that there has been a violation of the principles of natural justice

facts.text: On morning of July 26, 1960, shortage of 10 one-rupee notes in another packet made good by RBI staff, who bore grudge against R.K. Jain.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent has further stated that on the morning of July 26, 1960, ten numberes of rupee one denomination were found short in a packet

issues.text: Whether there has been a violation of the principles of natural justice in the domestic inquiry and whether a reasonable opportunity of defending himself has been provided to the workman in the said inquiry

anchor.surface_text: Whether there has been a violation of the principles of natural justice in the domestic inquiry and whether a reasonable opportunity of defending himself has been provided to the workman in the said inquiry has to be considered in the light of the circumstances referred to above.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal had jurisdiction to set aside the order of the management discharging the workman from service when there is no finding that the appellant had acted mala fide or with a view to victimise the employee

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General on behalf of the appellant ha,,-, urged three contentions  1  The Tribunal had no jurisdiction to set aside the order of the, management discharging the workman from service when there is no finding that the appellant had acted mala fide or with a view to victimise the employee

issues.text: Even if it is held that the evidence is not sufficient to justify the order of discharge, nevertheless under the last part of paragraph 521, cl. 10, sub-clause (c) of the Sastry Award, the appellant has full jurisdiction to pass the order of discharge

anchor.surface_text: 2  Even if it is held that the evidence is number sufficient to justify the order of .,discharge, nevertheless under the last part of paragraph 52 1, cl.  10 , sub-clause  c  of the Sastry Award, the appellant has full jurisdiction to pass the order of discharge

issues.text: Even assuming that the domestic inquiry conducted by the Bank was in any manner vitiated, the Industrial Tribunal erred in law in not giving an opportunity to the management to adduce evidence before it to establish the validity of the order of discharge

anchor.surface_text: and  3  Even assuming that the domestic inquiry companyducted by the Bank was in any manner vitiated, the Industrial Tribunal erred in law in number giving an opportunity to the management to adduce evidence before it to establish the validity of the order of discharge.

holdings.text: The second inquiry was not conducted at the instance of the workman.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, Mr. Ramamurthi is well founded in his contention and the view of the Industrial Tribunal in this regard is correct. We will not refer to the material on record which will support the above finding of the Industrial Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correspondence from Staff Association shows protests against second inquiry; management initiated it despite grievances and without informing workman timely; first inquiry abandoned due to RBI witnesses' refusal to cross-examine, not workman's fault.

holdings.text: There has been a violation of the principles of natural justice in the conduct of the domestic inquiry as the workman was not afforded a reasonable opportunity to place his defence before the Inquiry Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Under those circumstances, in our opinion, the Tribunal was justified in holding that there has been a violation of the principles of natural justice in the conduct of the domestic inquiry and that the workman was not afforded a reasonable opportunity to place his defence before the Inquiry Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Refusal to summon Pooran Singh and Sanjhi Ram unreasonable; workman incurred expense in first inquiry not his fault; management initiated second inquiry, bore expenses for own witnesses; special circumstances override normal rule that party produces own witnesses.

holdings.text: The domestic inquiry suffers from a very serious infirmity and in consequence the order of discharge based upon the findings recorded in such an inquiry cannot be sustained; such an order has been rightly set aside by the Industrial Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: the domestic inquiry suffers from a very serious infirmity and in consequence the order to discharge based upon the findings recorded in such an inquiry cannot be sustained. Such an order has been rightly set aside by the Industrial Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inquiry vitiated by violation of natural justice; Tribunal correctly set aside discharge order.

holdings.text: The last part of sub-cl. (c) of Cl. 10 of Paragraph 521 of the Sastry Award does not apply to justify the order of discharge.

anchor.surface_text: We are not inclined to accept this contention of the learned Solicitor... Therefore, the second contention of the learned Solicitor has to be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inquiry Officer found charges proved beyond doubt, not insufficiency of evidence; management never relied on this basis in show cause notice, discharge order, Tribunal, or SLP.

holdings.text: The Tribunal did not err in not giving an opportunity to the management to adduce evidence before it to establish the validity of the order of discharge.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it follows that the third contention of the learned Solicitor-General has also to be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Management defended solely on validity of domestic inquiry in written statement and evidence before Tribunal; never offered or requested to adduce independent evidence; no grievance raised in SLP.

holdings.text: A Tribunal can interfere with a punitive order of discharge based on domestic inquiry if there has been a violation of the principles of natural justice in the conduct of the inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The order terminating the services of the workman can also be set aside when there has been a violation of the principles of natural justice, in the conduct of the inquiry which led to the passing of the order of termination.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies principles from precedents like Tata Oil Mills and Ananda Bazar Patrika; no need for finding of mala fides or victimization if natural justice violated.

holdings.text: It is open to the management to justify the order of dismissal or discharge before the Tribunal by leading evidence if the domestic inquiry is defective, but it must choose to do so and request opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: if the enquiry is defective or if no enquiry has been held as required by Standing Orders, the entire case would be open before the tribunal and the employer would have to justify on facts as well that its order of dismissal or discharge was proper.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court precedents like Motipur Sugar Factory; management has right but did not avail here; no two-stage inquiry required.

precedents.citation: Tata Oil Mills Company, Ltd. v. Their Workmen 1

anchor.surface_text: Vide Tata Oil Mills Company, Ltd. v. Their Workmen 1 . The order terminating the, services of the workman can also be set aside when there has been a violation of the principles of natural justice, in the conduct of the inquiry which led to the passing of the order of termination.

precedents.case_name: Tata Oil Mills Company Ltd v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: circumstances which will justify the interference by the Tribunal are when the order of discharge is punitive, or mala fide or when it amounts to victimization or unfair labour practice

precedents.citation: Ananda Bazar Patrika P Ltd. v. Its Workmen 2 at page 606

anchor.surface_text: in Ananda Bazar Patrika P Ltd. v. Its Workmen 2 at page 606 as follows The extent of the jurisdiction which a Labour Court or an industrial Tribunal can exercise in dealing with such disputes is well-settled.

precedents.case_name: Ananda Bazar Patrika Pvt Ltd v Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: extent of the jurisdiction which a Labour Court or an industrial Tribunal can exercise in dealing with disputes regarding termination preceded by domestic enquiry
precedents.cited_holding: If the termination of an industrial employees services has been preceded by a Proper domestic enquiry which has been held in accordance with the rules of natural justice and the conclusions reached at the said enquiry are not perverse the Tribunal is not entitled to consider the propriety or the correctness. of the said conclusions.

precedents.citation: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workman 1

anchor.surface_text: is also laid down by this Court in Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workman 1 . Having due regard to the principles laid down in the above decisions, the contention of the learned Solicitor

precedents.case_name: Tata Oil Mills Co Ltd v Its Workman
precedents.cited_proposition: an officer holding the domestic inquiry can take no valid or effective steps to compel the attendance of any witness and that just as the management produces its witnesses before the officer concerned for giving evidence, it is the duty of the workman to take steps to produce his witnesses

precedents.citation: Ananda Bazar Patrika P Ltd. Its Workmen 2

anchor.surface_text: As emphasised by this Court in Ananda Bazar Patrika P Ltd. Its Workmen 2 , the termination of an employees service must be preceded by a proper domestic inquiry held in accordance

precedents.case_name: Ananda Bazar Patrika Pvt Ltd v Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: the termination of an employees service must be preceded by a proper domestic inquiry held in accordance with the rules of natural justice

precedents.citation: Workmen of Motipur Sugar Factory Private Ltd. v. Motipur Sugar Factory 1

anchor.surface_text: True it is, that it has been held by this Court in Workmen of Motipur Sugar Factory Private Ltd. v. Motipur Sugar Factory 1 page 588 at page 596 It is now well-settled by a number of decisions

precedents.case_name: Workmen of Motipur Sugar Factory Pvt Ltd v Motipur Sugar Factory
precedents.cited_proposition: where an employer has failed to make an enquiry before dismissing or discharging a workman it is open to him to justify the action before the tribunal by leading all relevant evidence before it
